content.description: Start left and follow easiest line to the left side of the broken pillar. Follow left crack after reaching broken pillar top. At second ledge I started up a slightly off-width crack that did not seem like a 5.3 (red dotted line in picture) so I followed the crack directly left of this crack. Build an anchor on top or belay from the rap station at the top of The Sorcerer. Rope drag wasn't too bad belaying from the rap station at the top of The Sorcerer. Deceptively long. It was a full 90-100 feet to the reach the rap station at the top of The Sorcerer.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches.
content.location: On the east end of Royal Columns between The Sorcerer and Contraction Action.

content.description: Climb up left side of broken pillar to its top, then up wide crack set on main wall.
content.protection: Gear to 4"

content.description: I am adding this route because the Yoder book says gear to 3" and it will be poorly protected if that is the largest you bring. We used a #4 Camalot in the middle and had to move it up higher, so you may want 2 #4.
content.protection: gear to 4". Build a gear anchor at the top; "The Sorcerer"'s rappel anchor is accessible from the second ledge up on the right.
content.location: Hard to describe, 5-6 cracks left of Journeyman crack and Twin Cracks. It is situated in the middle, with Too Far Out 5.5 on the left with a roof on it's left. Slot Machine 5.7 is on the right, also with small roof on it's right. This is getting close to the far left side of the wall.

content.description: Wide and (per the guidebook) dirty
content.protection: Gear to 4"

content.description:
I added this as 5.5, in keeping with the original rating. But be advised that it feels more like 5.7 when you move around the roof.

Starts out as double crack, jogs left around roof.
content.protection: Gear to 4".Bolted anchor.
content.location: 2 cracks left of Not so Easy.  Getting near the far north end.

content.description: A fun route that starts as a slab and a crack with plenty of holds. After the slab there is a dual crack section, and that is followed by 10-15 feet of off-width which finishes on the ledge that has anchors.
content.protection:
Gear up to 5".

The first half takes plenty of gear up to 2". The off width part in upper half is hard to protect. About 10 feet or so. If you have bigger cams, you will have some more options, but not much. As soon as the off-width part is done, you are on the ledge. Walk 5 feet left on the ledge and you should see the anchors: 2 bolts with rap rings.
content.location: Left of Nimrod's Nemesis. Starts on the protruding slabby section, left of the bush. There is isn't enough space to stand at the bottom of the slab. Belayer can stand just a tiny bit left in the inner corner which is quite spacious.

content.description: The straight in hand crack. An area classic. Sustained.
content.protection: Gear to 3". Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Left of First blood. See photo.

content.description: Jam and stem two corner cracks to the top.Two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Pro to 3".
content.location: Immediately right of Inca Roads.

content.description: Two cracks can be climbed by jamming, face holds, stemming, lots of options.  Good warm up or early lead.
content.protection: Doubles of .60-2", used mostly thin hands to hands.  Chains anchors above.
content.location: Belay in alcove area at Tree after rounding the corner from orange sunshine area, arete-acal is just above to your left.

content.description: Steep fist crack up two straight pillars.
content.protection: Gear to 3"

content.description: Another good crack line. Hands to fingers. Sucks up gear. Was rated 5.9 in the old guidebook.
content.protection: Gear to 3.5". Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Just left of Little Known Wonder. Right of Imperial Master. See photo.

content.description: Very sustained with multiple cruxes.  The hardest moves are probably on the starting slab, but it's not over till you rock onto the top ledge.  A proud send for the grade!
content.protection: 9 bolts w/ chain anchor.  Optional small cam (TCU) after the last bolt.  Originally a mixed route (5 bolts + gear).
content.location: Steepening flat pillar face left of Inca Roads (the classic 5.9).  Scramble up to first bolt from the right.

content.description: Start in the widening crack under the large roof.  Like Double Trouble, the angle continues to increase as you climb.  Jam the crack and use great face holds below the roof.  The crux is passing the roof and getting established in the wide crack above.  There are some good holds under the roof, and lots of small holds on the face.  Once past the roof, continue up the wide crack to the anchors.
content.protection: Big gear (to six inches) is helpful past the roof, but you can get smaller gear in if you look around.  Ends at a pair of chain anchors.
content.location: Climbs the wide crack just to the right of Double Trouble, below and then to the left of a large roof.

content.description: Newly rebolted in 2011.  A fun climb that gets better the higher you go.  Skirts the large roof on the right, then finishes directly above it with great position.  More than a few thought-provoking moves.
content.protection: 11 bolts.  Chain anchor.
content.location: Right side of main face.

content.description: An excellent sport route with a wide variety of interesting moves throughout. Start on the top of the column between Mush Maker and First Blood. Face climb up to the small roof, move right into the first crack then left into the second crack. The two cruxes for me were down low near the third bolt and about 2/3s the way up just before the cracks.
content.protection: 9 bolts to 2-bolt anchor with chains at the top of the column. Anchor is shared with Mush Maker and First Blood.
content.location: Starts on top of the column between Mush Maker and First Blood. See photo.

content.description: Thin to offwidth jams
content.protection: Gear to 4"

content.description: Fun route with the crux being a fun hand jam through a blank section.  Crappy, crumbly rock at the top makes the finish interesting.
content.protection: Gear from medium nuts to a 3" cam is useful.
content.location: Just left of Slacker, starts on a broken pillar and up the obvious crack.

content.description: Starts semi-wide with decent cupped jams in deep.  Slims down to good hands and intersects with a 1" arcing crack on the left before the final semi-wide section.  No mandatory OW technique necessary.  Fun jamming.
content.protection: Pro to 4".  Chain anchor.
content.location: Immediately right of Mush Maker.

content.description:
No anchor chains, requires gear anchor for follower. The follower can clean then get to anchor chains for First Blood/Hard Last/Mush Maker, then flick the rope over and lower down First Blood. Beware the choss at the top.

Similar to First Blood, OW technique somewhat more mandatory.
content.protection:
Gear to 5 inches.

Bolted anchor at the top.
content.location: OW crack right of First Blood, left of Slashed and Wild Children

content.description: The length of this climb is deceptive from the ground - it's a full 90-100 feet to the top.  Start out on easy, lower angled rock climbing the twin cracks that are easy on the hands and provide great protection.  The cracks continue to converge until you reach a horizontal break about 3/4 of the way to the top.  The last 30 feet has the best climbing with positive holds in the cracks and more great gear.  At the top, traverse right to the anchors above the roof.
content.protection: Standard rack to a #3 Camalot.  Fixed anchors to the right above Ignorant Pursuit.
content.location: Double Trouble is located closer to the eastern end of the wall, and climbs twin cracks immediately left of a column topped with a large overhang.

content.description: Crack to the right of the obvious roof. Not really a squeeze chimney like advertised in the book.
content.protection: Book says gear to 2.5"

climbs.name: Chasing Amy
climbs.fa: Michael Roy and the local clan

content.description: One of the longer climbs at the Columns.  Sussed out initially by the Tieton pioneers but never finished this sat for years with only anchors at the top and two bolts at the bottom.  Local BJ Mazzola had an eye on this route but never got around to equipping it.  Upon inspection it became obvious this route would make a great mixed route.  The whole route could have been bolted yet there are still a few of us on the Tieton who believe gear should be used when possible.  This seems especially fitting at the Columnes.
content.protection: QD's and gear to 2 inches.
content.location: Near the middle of the main face and close to Inca Roads.

content.description: I always thought this was an area classic. For 5.6 it is really fun with it's double crack. It and Western Front with all the easier cracks here were some of my first trad leads. Tieton climbs tend to be pretty stiff, which is good because ratings in Wa. tend to be soft, so this better prepares you for places like Co. Utah and Ca.
content.protection: gear to 4". I think I remember that there is a rap anchor way back so, it's good to belay the 2nd up.
content.location: when you go around corner buttress from the Orange Sunshine wall to the left this is a double crack to the right of the bolted 11a- Humble Pie

content.protection: Gear to 1.5 inches with optional larger pieces if doing the offwidth start. Small gear (less than 9 mm) for when finger crack peters out. Edit (July 2019): Ball and Chain now has its own anchors.
content.location: The finger crack to the right of Render Us Weightless (see photos).

climbs.name: The Arete-Acal
climbs.fa: Original Route: Brent & Nora Kertzman (1994)  Extension:  Andy Fitz & Tuck Russell (2011)

content.description:
This route used to end on a tiny ledge below a menacing block.  Then the block found its way to the ground, clearing the way for the route to go full length.

Scamper up the crack to the right and stretch over to pre-clip the first bolt.  Back on the ground, start directly under the roof at the bottom of the arete.  The hardest crux is still getting past the first bolt, but the extension adds a second crux where the big block used to sit.  In between is some fun technical edging and arete pulling.  The route ends on a mini-freestanding summit; for a total alpine experience, balance up and raise your arms in victory.
content.protection: 12 bolts.  Step across to  anchor bolts about ten feet above and behind the summit.  A 60 meter rope reaches the ground.

content.description: Take two cracks to the roof and continue around the roof to the top. The variation steps left of the roof, and takes the diagonal crack to the top.
content.protection: Pro to 4" for the variation.
content.location: Right of Mush Maker and First Blood. See photo.

content.description: Good route.  Mostly face climbing with good pro.  Can experiment with jams near the top.  Crux seems to be the very last move to the huge ledge.  Compared with the other ratings of routes in the area, this 5.7 seems pretty easy.
content.protection: Great gear of all kinds.  Small at the beginning, bigger (to 2") near the top.  Bolt anchors for top-roping or descent.  Can also walk off.
content.location: Route is on the far left of the Main Face.  It's the second route from the left.

content.description: Small fun route.
content.protection: Gear to 2.5 inches.
content.location: This is the leftmost route on Royal columns as per Tieton River Rocks guidebook. This is to the left (around the corner) from Unknown 5.7. You should see a think hand crack that ascends just right of a roof.

content.description: Starts in recessed cracks in the corner behind the bushes. The crack is good for hand jams. But the crack and face provides plenty of jugs that you wouldn't need any jams. I have kept the rating as 5.6 as per the guidebook, but this is way easier than the other 5.5s in this area. I would rate it 5.5.
content.protection: Gear to 2.5 inches. Once on the ledge, you can either use the anchors on your left (belongs to Unknown 5.7 route), or go onto the right ledge another 2 feet or so higher, and has bolted anchors with rap rings.
content.location: North end of the wall. To the right of Unknown 5.7 and left of Nimble Novice. (Note that there is one more "Unknown 5.6" which is to the left of Unknown 5.7, around the corner). Starts in the big corner under the bushes. This face has two cracks. This is the right crack.

content.description: Unlike the other double crack climbs that work up a face between two pillars, Twin Cracks climbs two cracks that are fairly close together in a corner.  Felt harder than the 5.6 rating, and much more difficult than it's neighbor - Double Trouble.  Climb up easy, lower angled rock to a small ledge on the left side.  Above this point, the climb is sustained with few rests.  Jam up the two cracks - stemming options are limited.  Great gear throughout.
content.protection: Large stoppers and cams to 4 inches (an old 4.5 Camalot is useful farther up).  all of the way up - a #4.5 Camalot is useful higher up.  There are some ratty slings hidden around a boulder at the top, but they were in bad shape with no rap rings.  A better option would be to scramble to the top and walk off, or stay roped up and traverse to the anchors above Ignorant Pursuit.  Not a good route to top rope.
content.location: West end of the wall, climbs the double cracks just to the left of Double Trouble.

content.description: Wide corner crack that funnels up to the same ledge as Not So Easy and adjacent routes.
content.protection: Book says gear to 4 inches. Larger would not be amiss.

content.description: This is a good line thats been somewhat neglected. It starts with an escape from a cool little pod into a nice layback section following the face crack up and slightly right till it nears the arete.  Nice holds appear as needed.  Then switch back 4-5 feet to the left to another crack and finish straight up. Its definitely climbable in its current state but there are a lot of big,loose blocks stacked above it that you'll have to negotiate on your way to a somewhat offline anchor.  We picked the one to the left above the now finished project(?)
content.protection: pro to 3" but you could put in a large piece down low.
content.location: Its a few columns right of Inca Roads and Imperial Master, distinguished by the pod down low with a somewhat rare for the area non-dihedral crack rising out of it

content.description: Start left and follow easiest line to the left side of the broken pillar. At the top of the broken pillar, follow double cracks to the top of the ledge.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches.
content.location: On the east end of Royal Columns between The Apprentice and Journeyman Crack.

content.description: Scramble to a ledge under an obvious roof. Pull around the roof to a hand/fist crack that widens to a squirm before the next ledge.
content.protection: Book says gear to 2.5 inches

content.description: Rarely climbed with several bushes on the first half.
content.protection: Gear to 2" and one fixed pin

climbs.name: Slash
climbs.fa: Full route: Andy Fitz, Ed Mosshart (2011)  Upper flake: Andy Fitz, Ed Mosshart (1988)

content.description:
Start up an easy/fun hand crack to a small ledge. Mantle and move left to the arete to climb an increasingly tricky three-bolt face/arete (crux), teetering over to the right to finish on the steep upper flake system.

An inobvious route, but fun and worth adding to a tour of Columns 5.10s.
content.protection:
Three bolts; a few medium cams for start; a small cam or two for the start of the upper flake and a larger cam or two for above. A #3 Camalot will make most people comfortable on upper flake, but a #2 Camalot is big enough to get you through if you put it in the right place.

Bolted anchor on the ledge above route. May still need chains.
content.location: Discontinuous crack system and pillar face immediately left of Wild Child corner/roof

content.description: The hardest part is dealing with the crappy rock at the top.  Getting around the roof is likely the crux, but it is not technically difficult.
content.protection: A wide range of pro is useful from medium nuts to 3" cams
content.location: First route on the Main Face when approaching from the Orange Sunshine area.  The start is right behind a tree.

content.description: Wide crack with bushes and good rests
content.protection: Gear to 5"

content.description: Chimney with limited protection
content.protection: Gear to 10"

content.description: Scramble up easy terrain to a high first bolt.  Then it's on like Donkey Kong with smears, edges, sidepulls and finger pods.  Finish either directly through the improbable looking roof of Render Us Weightless (5.8 or so) or by skirting to the right to the cool finger crack of Ball & Chain (5.10a).
content.protection: 5 bolts.  Gear for either finish.  Chains on top.

content.description:
Wander up the low angled start to the easy offwidth. Up the offwidth to the base of the the roof. Angle up and right thru the roof. Follow the sweet handcrack up the face and left at the end to the chains. While surmounting the roof is the crux its way easier than it looks.

5.10- Variation: There's a bolted direct pillar start that has become very popular. Follow the bolt line up the main pillar then continue on the original route up the roof.
content.protection: Pro to 4 inches is more than adequate altho you could put bigger stuff in if you wanted to.
content.location: Near the left edge of the main wall its a few columns left of Inca Roads. A 60m rope will get you down, a 50m would get you to easily downclimbable terrain
